Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Constructionism in Learning: Sustainable Life Cycle Engineering (CooL:SLiCE)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Including the consideration of sustainability, or the impact of human activity on the natural environment, into the design of consumer products is an important goal for both consumers and industry. However, engineering programs have struggled to find ways to effectively include the analysis of sustainability into engineering design education. This project will address this challenge by developing a cyberlearning environment that supports environmentally responsible product design through team-based and personalized design activities. The approach links 3D modeling and a product design database with an integrated manufacturing and supply chain analysis engine for environmental impact analysis. Team-based design activities will challenge students with sustainable product design problems using familiar products, such as skateboards, snowboards, and MP3 players. Successful implementation of the project will help to develop a new and affordable way for academic institutions to integrate sustainability topics into their curricula and prepare a skilled workforce that meets modern industry and consumer needs for sustainable product development.

The project's learning platform - Constructionism in Learning: Sustainable Life Cycle Engineering (CooL:SLiCE) - is based on the constructivist theory in learning and supports the development of multi-stage problem solving skills that will be built into a real-world problem context in which fundamental design, customization, and sustainability issues are integrated with an artifact likely to be personally meaningful to the learners. This approach will give learners an opportunity to realize the implications of their choices as consumers by specifically focusing on environmentally responsible design. The work will explore the hypothesis that the CooL:SLiCE platform will provide a medium for deeper learning in students of environmentally responsible life cycle product design. Sustainable life cycle engineering learning modules to be developed and delivered along with the CooL:SLiCE platform will facilitate investigations on the impact of different levels of autonomy on student learning of sustainability. A unit process modeling concept will be employed in the CooL:SLiCE manufacturing analysis engine for quantifying process and supply chain performance metrics. It has been established that the topic of sustainability attracts the interest of students from groups currently underrepresented in STEM disciplines. Consequently this project will contribute to broadening participation in STEM by helping to integrate sustainability analysis into the engineering curriculum. Moreover, this research will provide an understanding of the role of the e-learning platform as a medium to educate learners in environmentally responsible design. The structured learning activities will provide information that will further research efforts seeking to develop a cyber-based analysis tool for sustainable life cycle engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Constructionism in Learning: Sustainable Life Cycle Engineering (CooL:SLiCE) project was undertaken at Wayne State University, Oregon State University, Pennsylvania State University, and Iowa State University to provide an innovative cyberlearning platform for educating undergraduate engineering students about sustainability concepts. The CooL:SLiCE platform provides learning modules and supporting software tools for environmentally responsible design-based learning. This approach enables students? consideration of the impacts of the product and manufacturing processes on the natural environment.

Intellectual Merit: The CooL:SLiCE platform successfully demonstrates distributed cyberlearning for sustainable life cycle engineering. The learning platform supports an engineering design focus across the life cycle, specifically for product design, manufacturing analysis, and supply chain configuration. The platform was piloted in intercollegiate undergraduate capstone projects and graduate student projects for collaboratively designed drone customizations for sustainability. CooL:SLiCE is designed to provide students ?constructionist? (learning by doing) learning experiences appropriate for learning individually and along with others. CooL:SLiCE scaffolds learning by building upon prior knowledge to construct, or make, a meaningful artifact, which is critical in representing a student?s thinking about the task at hand and sharing with mentors and peers for feedback and critique. Learning modules were developed for use with the CooL:SLiCE platform that provide sustainable engineering scenarios for students to design artifacts they use and/or are familiar with (e.g., drones, tooling fixtures, and hand exercisers). To study their efficacy, these learning modules were incorporated into the curricula of several undergraduate and graduate engineering courses across the partnering universities.

Learning assessment data was collected throughout the project to inform ongoing development activities and collect summative findings (outcomes). A mixed-methods approach with qualitative and quantitative data provided a rich evaluation picture. The project team gained a deeper understanding of curriculum design, gauged student satisfaction with the learning modules, and collected faculty perceptions on how best to integrate CooL:SLiCE modules into their courses and other instructional contexts. Students were able to participate in pre- and post-activity surveys, which provided educational analysts with students? demographic information, insights into design decision-making, and personal reflections following the activities. Formative feedback was collected from different classes during the project, while selecting and creating assessment measures was done to assess not only learning, but also to provide student perceptions of the impact of CooL:SLiCE on their learning experiences.

Broader Impacts: This project responded to the need to increase awareness of environmentally responsible product design and broader sustainability issues in engineering education. A sustainability focus has previously been shown to disproportionately attract students from underrepresented groups to STEM disciplines, which can broaden participation in next generation engineering research and education. This project provided an excellent testing ground for evaluating the impacts of a constructionist learning approach on learners. More directly, this project has introduced engineering students to new concepts to impact their perspectives as consumers and environmentally impactful decision makers. Student and faculty knowledge and skills have been enhanced through the design of learning modules, cyberlearning platform, and questionnaires. Students and faculty from across the educational spectrum and across four institutions have been directly impacted by training and knowledge in education and engineering disciplines as a result of this project, including high school student interns, undergraduate students that participated in learning module assessment studies, and B.S., M.S., and Ph.D. students that participated in the research under the project. The CooL:SLiCE platform and related sustainable engineering activities involved at least 894 university students (656 undergraduate and 238 graduate) and 14 faculty (and instructors) in engineering courses offered at the four institutions.

Universities offer a variety of courses focused on the product life cycle; however, integrating key sustainability topics (e.g., sustainable design and industrial ecology) remains a challenge. This work helps to develop, at modest cost, a way for institutions to integrate sustainability into engineering curricula and to help prepare a workforce capable of meeting industry needs for sustainable product designers through cyberlearning. This project developed software tools and accompanying materials to aid engineering educators in industrial, manufacturing, and mechanical engineering and other fields to teach their students about sustainable design and manufacturing. Dissemination of CooL:SLiCE project results was aided by a faculty workshop. In addition, research results have been disseminated to engineering and educational researchers that will contribute to the growing body of knowledge, especially in constructionist educational methods. More directly, interdisciplinary interactions have been created between design and manufacturing engineering and social science disciplines (education and cultural anthropology) for faculty and students involved in this project, which will support ongoing and future research interactions of the project team. Virtual infrastructural resources have been developed and enhanced, including a multicopter design repository from disassembly and measurement of several multicopters, as well as a cyberlearning portal and online analysis modules for sustainable design and manufacturing engineering education (http://cindi.eng.wayne.edu/coolslice.html).
